summary: Email correspondence between attorneys regarding the filing of a Second Circuit decision in Brown v. Maxwell (July 3, 2019) and the Government's opposition to Oath Inc.'s motion to intervene in US v. Gatto. The email includes a disclaimer about attorney-client privilege.

persons.name: Jonathan M. Albano
persons.context: Attorney at Morgan, Lewis & Bockius LLP who sent an email requesting consent to file a court decision and was copied on the Government's opposition filing.

persons.name: Kathleen A. Slowe
persons.context: Assistant to Jonathan M. Albano, mentioned in the email signature.

persons.name: Victoria Peng
persons.context: Listed as a recipient on the Government's opposition filing email regarding Oath Inc.'s motion to intervene.

persons.name: Steve Moore
persons.context: Listed as a recipient on the Government's opposition filing email regarding Oath Inc.'s motion to intervene.

persons.name: Mark
persons.context: Listed as a recipient on the Government's opposition filing email regarding Oath Inc.'s motion to intervene (last name appears redacted or truncated).

connections.description: Albano is an attorney at Morgan, Lewis & Bockius LLP and Slowe is listed as his assistant.
Both are legal professionals involved in the same case (US v. Gatto) as indicated by email correspondence.

events.title: Second Circuit Decision in Brown v. Maxwell
events.description: The Second Circuit issued a decision in the case Brown v. Maxwell, which is referenced as an attachment in the email correspondence.

events.title: Government Files Opposition to Oath Inc. Motion
events.description: The Government filed an opposition to Oath Inc.'s motion to intervene for the limited purpose of obtaining materials in US v. Gatto.

locations: United States Attorneys Office Southern District of New York
keyFacts: The document is an email chain regarding legal proceedings in US v. Gatto, specifically involving Oath Inc.'s motion to intervene.
Jonathan M. Albano of Morgan, Lewis & Bockius LLP seeks to file a Second Circuit decision (Brown v. Maxwell, July 3, 2019) with the Court.
The Government filed an opposition to Oath Inc.'s motion to intervene, with an unredacted version provided to the Court ex parte.
The email includes a standard legal disclaimer about attorney-client privilege and confidentiality.
The correspondence involves multiple attorneys, including Victoria Peng, Steve Moore, and Mark, indicating a collaborative or adversarial legal process.
